I am not a big fan of Chinese "fast food", but I am also open to try new things and give places a chance. I am well aware of the lack of customer service of majority of Chinese places I've been too (although some are great) but this one takes first place out of all and really brings it to a whole new level.

I came here for the first time and sat myself in front of the waitress taking orders. I politely asked to see the menu after waiting for some time. After looking at the menu for some time and trying to get eye contact with the waitress getting orders, no one approached me to get my order even though I was in front of the servers, I then politely asked for the server to get my order.  After waiting for 40 minutes, I decided to follow up on my order only to be told that it was going to be another 15 minutes, thats almost an hour of waiting.  I asked them why does it take that long to make garlic chicken hoping to get an honest answer that someone dropped the ball, she then replied by saying "there were a lot of people before me, do you still want your order"  do I want my order? I wanted to burn the place down but that is obviously not an option. And the waitress didn't even apologize. What really happened was she forgot to place my order and didn't have the decency to admit it.  Oh well, I guess it goes with out saying that I am never going back to this place again.

Don't expect this place to respect your time so be prepared to wait.
author: John G.

description:
I've been a fan of Henry's food since it was just the single storefront on Kearney. And I've had good meals at the franchises on Mission, Sansome, Natoma and Sacramento. But the management on Bryant Street is incompetent, rude, and openly hostile to (attempted) customers. I called in a simple order for pick-up and was told it would be ready in 15 minutes. I arrived as instructed, paid for my food, and then waited another 20 minutes without explanation. When I asked the manager when he thought my food would be ready, he yelled "do you want your money back?" I actually just wanted my Henry's Special (which is usually excellent) but apparently had no choice. My money was returned with no apology.

Hey, I like their recipes -- and have had good experiences at the other Henry's -- but I'll never return to the Bryant St. location. Too many choices in SF to be treated that poorly.
author: john k.

description:
first time at this Henry's for me. 
usually go the the sansome one. 
tried an old favorite the dumpling. either my bud's changed or the dumpling's changed.

eats: dumpling(4.5)
-skipped the hot oil, what was left is the soy sauce. lots of it. not so good
-6ish dumplings had dryish meat inside, not juicy.
should go with the hot oil next time
or the henry bacon lunch special over rice

takeouts:
-order took about 20 minutes which seems a long time.
-decor is very casual. kind of rundown,
-fanny's packed down the block.
author: Victor G.

description: We came in at lunch time. For 15 minutes no one came to take our order. After they did the people who came after Us were getting their orders before us.Service Sucks.
author: Harsh A.

description: Really great authentic Hunan food! This place is perfect for people that want a nice spicy meaty meal. My personal favorite are their ribs. At lunch they also provide free sweet and sour soup! The only thing I would say though is the food tends to be on the over salty side.
author: Andy A.

description:
Super Cheap Chinese food with huge portions.

Everything tastes okay, but to me it seems that all the food has the exact same sauce/taste to it with a different meat type.   

Get: 
String beans and shrimp or beef
Fried Cod
Kung Pao Chicken
Short Ribs

Okay:
Meat Pie
author: Steven F.

description: OMG!! I am part Chinese so I can tell you that this is the closest thing to authentic Chinese food besides my mom's cooking! The dumplings are to die for, the sauces are peppery, hot goodness; and the atmosphere is so friendly!! I love this place!!
author: Addy Belle J.

description:
wow. this place has very tasty food and great portion size.

they are beside "SO" which is also a great place. i would rate more to henry hunan.
author: Kumar G.

description:
I work pretty close to Henry's Hunan and I've been coming here to eat at least once a week for the past couple of years. I'm pretty sure I'll keep coming back until something drastic happens. 

Jason and the crew there is very nice and always working hard to give the best service. Sometimes the food can take a couple minutes more to be ready, but those extra couple minutes make all the difference when making food, let alone great food. 

They have lunch deals that will keep your wallet heavy, will satisfy all of your taste buds, and will probably leave you with some to eat later. 

The DUMPLINGS are amazing!!!
author: Johnny K.

description: I gave this place 2 stars because what I saw on a menu was meet pie for 6.50. However i wanted a replacement of beef instead of pork I was recommended huang style beef but an extra dish of beef was included on the side which resulted in paying almost $20.00.
author: Azziz I.

description: I'm lying at home wondering if this nauseous feeling is going to get worse. Food was terrible- I never should have continued eating- it seemed a little "off". (Sweet and sour chicken). They were out of soup AND spring rolls  (what Chinese restaurant runs out of soup or spring rolls at 6pm???!?). They forgot the appetizer. I had to get up to pay and when I asked to take the leftovers home the guy handed me a bag and two containers. Oh, and bathroom was one of the more disgusting I've seen in a while. Strange how this location can be SO much worse than the others. Never again.
author: Chris P.

description: Terrible service! I waited for 70 minutes but I got nothing! I will never go there again! Never ever!
author: Yiping L.

description: Henry's is amazing. It's awesome Chinese food and made quick.  My go-to picks are pork fried rice, chicken with vegetables, and broccoli chicken. And you get free tea with your meal if you dine in. I've been to the North Beach locations dozens and dozens of times over the past 3.5 years and never had a bad experience. LOVE this place!
author: Kristy A.

description:
Awwww,  Henry's is the MAN.

Every time my former boss would say to me, "Let's get Chinese today", I would do the human version of a tail wag. 

Henry's food is consistently good. Prepare to come hungry, as their portions are HUGE (A.K.A. 'Family Style'), and since I don't like sharing, I like to see if I can finish the whole meal in one sitting, because I'm a fat-ass. 

Lunchtime is particularly hectic for these guys, so call ahead if you want your meal to-go, as it can take anywhere from 15-20 mins to prepare. 

My former co-worker and I loooooved the Kung Pao Shrimp. It's right on the cusp of being 'too spicy'. Ohhhh, how I miss their Kung Pao Shrimp. Our bosses loved the Spicy and Hot Rock Cod Filet. 

Sometimes these guys will throw in some Spring Rolls at no additional charge.

As an added bonus, they never use M.S.G. in any of their food. Just delicious, piping hot, perfectly prepared Hunan Chinese food every time. 

Even though I moved back to the East Bay, I will definitely be making the drive to SF to visit this place again in the near future. This place easily gets five stars. Thanks for  party-rockin', Henry's Hunan Restaurant!
author: Jen O.

description: These guys are so fantastic.  Salty, spicy, and satisfying!
author: Kristen S.

description:
The service is so nice, the portions are huge and more importantly, you can find Chinese Chinese food here!

LOVE the dumplings, meat pie and whatever the waiter recommend.
author: Ji C.

description:
great food! if you like authentic spicy hunan food, come here and ask for the recommended menu (if you are not chinese they will give you a menu that has generic items such as kung pao chicken, ask for a different one!)

the only con of this place is that the wait time is INSANELY LONG! they only have one cook in the back and usually waits for several of the same dish to be ordered to cook a batch, meaning you have to wait very long. a 30-60 min wait is minimum. One time we waited for 90 minutes before the first item was served.
author: Bo D.

description:
Haven't been there in awhile, but when I worked at Sega, my co-workers and I ate there about once a week.

Their combination Chow Mein is hands down the best I have ever had. 

Not a fancy place, but the food quality and portions are great. I love this place.
author: Brian M.

description: I used to go to their Sansome street location, but that location closed recently. On my first visit, I came with my girlfriend only to be told that none of the standard items that I had ordered in the past were available- no potstickers, no hot and sour soup, and no fish, and then we were told that it would be an hour wait. The restaurant was half full. I was the only white person in the restaurant. We walked out. Suspicious, but I decided to give it another go. I went back a second time, this time by myself, tried to order a similar line up, and got the same reception. I will not be returning.
author: John S.

description:
Quite authenticated consider it's in a area outside of the Chinatown. 
The price is very affordable, and the spicy keeps you sweat, which is great.
author: Zuck L.

description: this place has really authentic hunan food，don't come here if you cannot eat spicy food or you like americanized chinese food
author: Yuan G.

description:
In my perfect world the perfect chow mein would be perfectly fried noodles and meat, that's it.  Henry's hasn't perfected the Chicken Chow Mein of my perfect world, but they've come pretty darn close.  With the version at Henry's (pictured) you'll find an occasional bean sprout, a tiny bit of shaved carrot, a single sliver of onion and a little green onion to go with a large portion of noodles and cubes of all white meat chicken.  If you like noodles and meat, you're going to like the chow mein at Henry's, and because it is a Hunan restaurant you can bet that your food will be effectively spicy.

That's another beautiful thing at Henry's Hunan.  If you can't handle the heat the kitchen will be more than happy to season your food to your preferred spicyness or mildness should that be the case.

I often get carried away with ordering food and end up over-eating instead.  Seriously, one order of chow mein and a beverage will fill you up, but I had to try the Dumplings too.  My server was seated at a table folding these when I walked into the restaurant; one look at the ingredients was enough to convince me to try these.  They're just like potstickers with a lean pork filling with just a bit of cabbage and ginger, but instead of being pan-fried crisp on one side these are steamed then presented in a bowl with a light, spicy soy sauce and chopped scallions (also pictured).  The dumplings were very good.

The service was excellent, but I went there during an off-peak hour so I was the only diner there at the time.  Inexpensive and less than two blocks from my work, I wonder why I haven't eaten here more often.  In my perfect world I will.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I am here right now. Its been 75 minutes and I am still waiting for food. Zero stars.
author: Vidur S.

description:
Stood around for 5-10 minutes (at 8pm) while the restaurant staff all sat at a table in plain clothes and ate.  The restaurant was half full and after someone finally got up and mumbled towards us... We pressed them and pressed them for a couple of minutes and we were told that we should order takeout or else it would take over an hour.  "Well, if we order takeout how long will it take?"  "Over an hour for takeout, too".

My wife said it best: "get your shit together and choose to run a restaurant".

This had a strong feel of an older couple breaking their back in the rear and the younger (30-ish) kids up front running it into the ground.
author: James R.

description:
This spot is hard to assign a simple star rating. It is a place of extremes and I think there are some lovable things and some mediocre things. So I give it 3 stars and here is why. 

It isn't your average Americanized corner beef-and-broccoli shop. They market themselves as distinctly Hunan and spicy. 

My favorite thing about Henry's is the menu. It has odd and personal dishes that have a bit more explanation than just a list of ingredients. The menu speaks to you. 

I tried a soup, dumplings, and a pork and cabbage dish. Pork is a big feature on the menu. 

In the case of the main dish, it came out very greasy and the pork had been cooked at least twice...and perhaps at least once too many times. 

The dumplings were steamed and in a spicy soy sauce. Pretty good. 

The soup was solid but not special. 

The people are nice enough but not so attentive. The space is plain but that doesn't matter for this kind of meal. 

The do have a TV on the wall which is tacky and distracting to the staff and guests in a resturant. It is probably a symptom of this also being the living room of a bunch of people who spend all their waking hours in this resturant. 

I didn't make any particular requests about the spiciness level and they didn't ask. It came out mildly spicy. 

In the end I would say if you are a big eater who likes rich food that is outside the the norm and you like homespun dining experiences then this is a good spot for you. Otherwise, there are a lot of nice Chinese food options in SF to choose from. 

If you work in the area I could see this as a part of a regular rotation.
author: Erik F.

description:
Insider Tip #1: If SO next door is busy, and you are hungry, come here! It's pretty effing good.

Insider Tip #2: "Mild" dishes are still relatively spicy, so careful when you ask for "Spicy" or "Extra Spicy" - YEOUCH!

Insider Tip #3: Ask for the garlic chilli sauce, which they don't normally offer to customers. It will transform your meal, your palate and your life, in that order.
author: Joshua L.

description: Worst service ever in any restautant. We went for dinner where not many people were in. After 30 minutes, we were told the dish will take some tine and other late comers would get first due to preorder. After another 30 minutes, we asked how long to wait and got answer of not sure. We urged the waitress to  check and got rejected. The waitress was careless and didn't provide any explanation or water during wait. And she cleaned other table super slow as if she didn't want to do the work.
author: Michael Z.

description:
We felt totally unwelcome here.

I may be reading too much into it, but the difference in quality of our experience versus those of the Asian duos which arrived at the same time seemed striking.

SO had a huge line and this place had decent star rating so we decided to try it.  When we walked in I was hopeful because it seemed popular with a Chinese crowd- we were the only Anglo folks in the place.

However, it seemed we got far worse service.  They had a pile up of unbused tables.  After they cleaned those  they sat the Chinese couple who arrived after us, then gave us a table, then sat two Asian guys.

We weren't given menus, water, silverware, or anything while those two tables were. We got up and got ourselves menus. Their orders were taken, then ours was.  Then server came back and told us the kitchen was really backed up, it would be a least 45 minutes.  We got the message and left, and they immediately sat the Chinese couple waiting at the table we'd vacated.
author: Alice L.

description: Solid food, nothing too crazy, but very good chicken wings.
author: Rohan S.

description: On a scale of 1 to 100 (100 is the best) for service, this place gets a ZERO  (and that is being VERY generous).  Don't bother.  Trust me.  We ordered the food from a server who clearly didn't give a crap, then sat for 45 minutes waiting for something, ANYthing to arrive.  Nothing arrived.  No beer.  No nothing.  We walked out and will never (EVER) go back.
author: Thomas M.

description: It took almost an hour to get my food. I ordered medium spicy and it was extremely spicy (I can handle more spice then most people I know, I eat spicy foods every other day). Water gave me a fork instead of chopsticks probably because I was white. They never checked in on me to see how I was doing. Table was wobbly. Portions were large and food was probably authentic though.
author: Jeff K.

description: At the restaurant now everything we want led is sold out, and takes soooooo long for service. Tbd about food quality.
author: Chad P.

description: There's a secret Chinese menu, which is way better than the English menu.  Authentic Hunan food, and as spicy as you can handle... no joke. I can handle spice and this place made me sweat like blind lesbian at a fish market. In fact, I don't even remember exactly what I ordered -- yes, the kind of spicy where your ears start ringing and you go into a burning, euphoric trance. It was great. Oh, and the owners are super friendly too.
author: N H.

description: I work across the street  and one day I decided to have lunch at this location. What a horrible mistake on my part. Due to being a first time customer I asked for a menu. After making my menu choice I attempted to place my order. The person taking my order informed me that it would be at least a 30 minute wait and that they usually only take phone orders. I will never spend money at this location and would not recommend anyone else go here unless you like rude people and slow service.
author: Jamel W.

description:
So, I see what happened. So, a child of San Tung opened up right next door to this Henry's Hunan location and appears to have killed the HH lunch business. So how mean!

Skip the trendier So and enjoy a delicious meal at Hunan, with hearty portions and all the great dishes like Diana's Meat Pie, Cold Chicken Noodles, Bean Sprout Salad, Dumplings.......YUM.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Would give zero star if I could. Service is horrible. Come here only if you are willing to wait for over 2 hours.
author: Qiming Y.

description:
I wanted to give three stars cause service was so nice but wow the food is just not tasty.

Dumplings and no flavor

Spicy rock cod had a great sauce. The fish itself had a weird texture, not sure what it was.

Hot and sour soup was nice

Enjoyed the green beans the most, but have had better.
author: Foodlover B.

description: I got a raving review from a family member about this place so we had high hopes when we decided to try it. Those hopes and dreams were quickly smashed. Placed a pick up order on a casual Monday, didn't have 4 of the 7 dishes we originally intended to order, okay Henry don't let me down now man. Then when we did get an order in the estimated time for pick up was 30 minutes then she changed her mind to 50 minutes. I'm sorry, 50 minutes for Chinese food? Alright fine. THEN when we went to pick it up a solid 50 minutes later, still isn't ready she says come back in 8-10 minutes. 10 minutes later, still isn't ready. Classic. Another 10 minutes goes by. In terms of what we finally made it home with 4 thousand years later...chicken fried rice with hot spicy sauce was pretty decent, would order again. Henry's special was a big meh. Hard pass. Chicken chow mein not great.  Long story short I expected to have my mind blown and the only thing mind blowing about this experience was how long I had to wait. I'm gonna go ahead and say that I most likely would not return.
author: Taylor V.

description:
I have only ever eaten at the HH on Sansome, but, I spotted this locale when leaving TJ's a month or so ago, so, I decided to go with some co-workers

I had my usual, the smoked ham rice plate.  It was as good as ever, though, there was a bunch of oil/grease left on my dish after I inhaled my lunch - I don't remember the dish being that greasy when I had it at the Sansome locale.

I mean, sometimes it's good to have grease on your ham, and sometimes, just not.

Ya feel me??
author: Johnny L.

description: Best Chinese food in bar area. Also the most spicy one.
author: Huahan Z.

description:
Dude, where else can you get the biggest bowl of noodles, veggies, meat, and black bean sauce in the world for like $6? That said, I think I'll stick to the rice plates next time, but huge props for providing value. I took about 80% of the noodle bowl home, refried it with garlic, mushrooms, and an egg, and it was lunch for two!

Hope it stays open, it looks like SO is sharking some of their business. It's a solid 3 star from me and I hope to keep it in my lunch rotation whenever I'm working from home.
author: Josh K.

description: We go there because the food is good. Like the other reviews said the service is terrible and only come if u have time because they say half hour but it's like over an hour of wait to get food. I think this maybe our last time. Hope they can change their ways about service. I know there are other Hunan restaurants and nothing like this one on service.
author: Nick P.

description:
I was originally going to go to SO next door, but they were closed for Spring Break.  Against my coworker's warning, I went to Henry's Hunan instead.  

The food took a little too long to prepare, the noodles I got (with pork sauce) were oookay (not enough flavor), and to top it off, I found a piece of plastic the size of a quarter in my dumpling.

I've had good food at other Henry's Hunan restaurant locations, but I was disappointed by this one.  Next time I want Chinese food at work, I'll be trying out SO.
author: Leslie C.

description: Hate to give a place a bad review, but this place definitely deserves it. We had to walk out before eating our meal. This is the dirtiest place I've ever been to with the worst service, and believe me that's saying something.
author: Jeff L.

description: We wend in the afternoon and it was not busy. We like everything we ordered. The food was served fast. Will stop by next time.
author: Tracy D.

description: This was my introduction to Henry's Hunan. I used to work in the SomArts building, and Jeff managed Henry's. I had complimentary hot and sour soup and piping hot tea while I decided. I almost never ordered from the lunch menu because with offerings such as black bean squid, smoked meats, and spicy green beans. Many people have written about their dumplings. I'll agree in that they are tasty. Also, they make the best rice. Chinese rice should be sticky. Too many restaurants serve rice that you cannot eat with chopsticks.
author: Therese M.

description:
Just stopped by. The restaurant is only half full but was told that I'd better leave because the dish will not be ready in an hour ......

I will not go there again. There are many better Chinese restaurants in sunset
author: Li C.

description:
Meat pie. Best Ever.

*drops mic, walks off stage*
author: Jorge H.

description: I would love to give 0 star. bad service. Only one waitress was doing service. No menu, we've been waiting about 20min, nobody bring any dishes even rice.  Also, there have another guy waiting even longer than us, he seems really uncomfortable, drank up three waters, eventually he left. We waited about another 5min, then we left too, even I am Chinese who loves Chinese food, for this kind of Terrible customer experience, never want to go back!!!
author: Blair Z.

description: How is it, that they don't have items on the menu. Bryant street location is awful! Update your menu and website!
author: Brian G.

description: Super Yummp! The best Hunan resturant in bay area!!!!!don't want to go to any others!!!
author: Xiaofeng W.

description: I went to Henry Hunan with some friends. The place is not one of those well decorated restaurants, you know. But as far as the taste is concerned, I'm happily surprised. It seems that they do not add MSG (which I don't like since it makes many Chinese food taste similarly). Instead, the chilli brings an aromatic flavor which I really enjoy, although I wasn't into spicy food particularly.
author: Joseph C.

description: JESUS FUCKING CHRIST. This my first time come here and i swear the god I will not come here again. We came here at 8.30 PM. It is fucking 9.42PM already and there is no one single starter yet. Jesus fucking christ. I look around our table. Three other tables are all empty. We are starving. I can see stars over my head. No starter yet, but at least give us some appetizer or snacks. But there is none. not single of them. holy crap. There is a serious management problem of the restaurant. There are only two chiefs in the kitchen. and the restaurant is full of people waiting for food. Why dont hire more chiefs!! holy shit. Demonds exceeds supply too much. why they cant balance it! And I still dont understand why the hell there are still so many people come to this restaurant while people willing to wait for more than 1 hour. It is now 9:50 pm and there is still no one single starter. Never ever come here again.
author: Kevin J.

description: My favorite part of eating at Chinese restaurants is the traditional courtesy bestowed upon customers. The greeting, seating, menu, glass of water, and pot of tea have come to be something I expect. When I arrived at Henry's on a Saturday at noon, I was given the Stink Eye and told they wouldn't be open for another 20 minutes. Basically: "Go away." So I did.
author: Joseph T.

description:
There spicy food is spicy OK???  Thats good..  There chicken tastes like chicken..  There salad???  Like salad.  They do it all right and for a good price and thats good cause its San Fran..   NO BODY wants to pay millions of bucks for chow fun.. 

Could eat there noodles all day !! Spilled some on my pants eating in the truck but there not to greasy so it didn't stain haha !! 

Going back here alot from now on so you could find me here some times..  Say HI or you could be a wiredo staring to I guess..
author: Xavior G.

description: This particular Henry's is a big thumbs down for me.  I love the Henry's on Church street but this SOMA location just needs some good ole' fashioned TLC.  The inside is multi-colored and looks a bit run down with tables of food left from patrons long gone.  The server was friendly and nice but the food was a miss.  I ordered the Orange chicken with brown rice and having paid extra for my specialty rice selection I received white rice with some mushy chicken.  It was awkward but I ate it.  I will give it one more chance since the Velvet Chicken is near and dear to my heart.  Let's just hope that this particular Henry's can pull through.  Now if I can just get past the facade...
author: Kevin J.

description:
OMG, one of my faves. 

It's funny...I've never really been a picky eater, but growing up one of the few things I couldn't eat was spicy food...but as I've gotten older I've learned to handle myself better and as a result...this is now one of my favorite restaurants. 

My mom used to come here when they had their location in Chinatown and so, naturally, she introduced both me and my brother to their food. 

Things to try: 

Diana's pie: yes, it is greasy, but IT IS TOTALLY worth it. My brother is a...how should I say...purist, and refused to eat anything greasy or oily to be more healthy (funny, I should be doing that...not him) BUT even he is willing to eat this dish. It has spicy ground pork, lettuce, and some fried, crispy top and bottom. Please try it! 

Noodles: I'm not sure exactly what this dish is called, but I know it's noodles with spicy ground pork and lettuce?? It's one of my favorites, but then again, I'm a really big fan of noodles. 

Marty's special and Henry's special: I think one of them has scallops, chicken, and ham? All in a spicy sauce....which a delicious! And the other is ham and some veggies?? It's more smoky in flavor....both of these are pretty good. 

My mom said Marty was another brother or son or some family member....my cousin made the general rule of thumb that if it's named after the restaurant it HAS to be good...and I feel like this is accurate! 

If you're not a fan of spicy, don't come here...or ask for super super mild things. Obviously, if you're a health freak or on a diet...don't come here either...this is greasy, but good and hearty Chinese food.
author: Alison N.

description:
One of the my favorite restaurants in the bay area. 

Go there once a week on average.
author: Jack G.

description:
Worst place I've been to in years.

Not only are you going to sit in that cockroach infested place where the only thing they bring you is luke warm water for 45 minutes - no, it was not busy. 

Cockroaches, horrible service, carve out 1:30hrs to be served on an empty lunch break.
author: R M.

description:
Came in here starvin' like marvin, LEFT here starvin' like marvin


My friend and I decided to give this place a go since SO was closed. (Noooo!!!)  We ordered the chicken fried rice, chicken string beans and little something chicken wings.  Everything... was so bland -___-.  The only thing that was bearable was the string beans with chicken and that was because my friend threw a WHOLE lotta hot sauce on there. We were literally only there for 15 mins, ate whatever we had on our plates after scooping it from family style and just bounced.  We had so much food left you'd think that we ordered TO GO.  


I feel bad for the folks that asked us what we'd recommend. My friend and I looked at each other like uh... nothing?? But told them to get the string beans but ask for it to be "hot", maybe it'll be tastier than mild?


Needless to say, won't be back.
author: Annie C.

description: I will give 2-3 stars for food, but the service is really killing the deal. I've been here 3 times and every time had to wait at least half an hour for the food while there were only a few customers in the restaurant. Today we waited for one hour and the food was not even prepared!!!!! Of course no one ever came to our table to check if we need anything or at least kind enough to let us know we probably have to wait for another hour for the food. The story ends with me and my family left with empty stomach as we can't afford to starve ourselves for another hour. I will never come back to this restaurant again or recommend to anyone.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Finally a place that makes spicy spicy. We ordered take out which was ready in 10 minutes. 

Eggplant salad was light and tangy in a fragrant vinaigrette. 

Ma Po Tofu was spicy but I was expecting the tofu to be fried. Probably saved me some calories with the silky tofu. 

Chicken and mixed veggies made spicy was really good with big pieces of broccoli, bok choy and carrots. 

*Bonus* Brown rice is available! 

Can't wait to come back and try other dishes.
author: Kim W.

description:
If I could give this place zero stars I would.  I hate giving bad reviews but this place deserves one.  I have been eating here for 18 years.  When Jeff was in charge, it was wonderful.  Food was served quickly and tasted great.  Jeff was always friendly and had a smile on his face.  

I moved out of SF and can't make it back unless I am in town a lot but when I am, I always stop in to get takeout here to bring back home with me.  The last 4 occasions I actually ate at the restaurant and whomever is the server now is very rude.  He only serves his friends or chinese people and you have to basically go up to someone else at the facility to be served.  I didn't want to believe that someone was that obvious about discrimination so I convinced myself that the last 4 visits was just an oversight on his part and that he was just bad at his job.   I loved the food so I put up with the previous bad service.  However, this last visit, it was obvious what was going on and I now understand why every time I eat here there are only chinese people in the restaurant.  We walked in to be seated and he walked right passed us ignoring us, walked up to a chinese couple behind us and seated them while we grabbed our own seats.  He then gave them a menu, took their order and walked to the kitchen. 

We sat waiting for menus as he continually walked back and forth greeting other chinese patrons.  He gave everyone else (again, either his friends or chinese patrons) menus and ignored us.  Finally, another woman brought us menus.  Tick Tock, Tick Tock...we waited over 25 minutes for two entrees and my spouse had already finished hers before i even got my order.  

The male server then goes outside and smokes with his friends and smoke is coming into the restaurant (Not real fun to eat while smelling smoke).  Then he comes back in, grabs the water pitcher to refill glasses on the tables and only fills the glasses of every chinese table and walks right by ours even though we made it quite clear that we wanted water by putting our glasses at the very end of the table so he could see them.  I finally went and grabbed the water pitcher and served our own water.  

We had enough and my spouse asked him why he is not serving us but taking care of everyone else in the restaurant.  He looked at her and as she was in mid sentence walked away saying nothing and glaring at us.  What a jerk!  Then after this happened, two guys walked in (not chinese) and he ignored them too.  They stood there for at least 5 minutes waiting to be greeted as he walked right passed them.  We mentioned our bad service to them and one of them said to us "Glad we aren't the only ones that thought he wasn't serving us because we aren't chinese".  Wow, how this place is still operating is beyond me.  

If they want to ignore paying customers because of race, then why don't they just become a private facility and not open to the general public.  Too bad, cause I love their food but this guy is toxic and I am choosing to spend my money elsewhere.
author: Amie G.

description:
This review is for take-out only. I've only ever had a few items from here but loved them. Diana's Meat Pie, I know sounds odd and weird, but it's good. It's a chinese pizza/quesadilla type of thing. It's using chinese fried pancake for the top and bottom and the inside is lined with shredded lettuce and ground beef with sauce. that's all it is, so it's like a Chinese quesadilla. 

The other item that we love is the Henry's special. This location is a hit-or-miss on this entree but overall still good. It's a mix of chicken, shrimp, scallop mixed with bell peppers with a hot spicy red sauce. Spoon that baby over white rice and you've got yourself a delicious meal! 

I wouldn't ever eat in here, it's a bit of a dive and parking is tough on Bryant street, so I just double park and run out to get the food.
author: Grace L.

description: We were the only people eating here this evening, but this didn't bother me. The place was clean, if not a bit too quiet- could have used a little music. I really liked the food. The soup with spinach egg and pork was different, in a good way. Very hearty and filling. I REALLY enjoyed the Marty's Special. Smoked ham in a Chinese restaurant sounded a bit odd at first but it was awesome. So smoky and flavorful and delicious. Sure, there was a good amount of oil at the bottom of the dish, but I didn't care. They also serve brown rice along with white. Prices are average.
author: Julie S.

description: BEST Chinese food in town. I've been to many of Henry's Hunans but this one stands out. The food is very delicious. However, the service is okay. You get a big portion for a great price. I highly  recommend this restaurant to people who love spicy & flavorful Chinese food.
author: Henna A.

description:
Good, good good.  Been wanting to go to one of these for a while.  A friend was in town from NY and the opportunity presented itself to go within a very short walk from the Civic Center Motor Inn where she's staying.  Best dumplings I've ever had. These guys put the sauce in the bowl they're served in, yum.  It lightly coats them as you stir it around.  Had the first item on the menu, can't remember the name but there's a great story about the dish that drew me to it.  My friend had MooShoo Pork and loved it.

Tried the meat pie w/ sauce to say we did cuz it's one of their quirky specialties...tasty!  I'd order it again.  

My friend was happy to have lots of leftovers for the next couple days.  We were there during lunch on a Wednesday. Got there around 11:45. It never got super busy. Wait staff was very attentive. Decor is cafeteria tables and chairs...that's all you need.  

I don't think I'll bother trying to get to the one in the Financial District any longer.  I'll just pop in here.  Might have to make it a pre-Giants game spot in the process.
author: Sport G.

description:
I like Henry's... the food is always consistently good, and you get a TON of it for not alot of cash. They use a good combination of spices for some nice flavors and they don't seem to try to over-do it. I also like the fact that they don't try to Americanize the food, either.

The staff are very friendly and efficient, though the decor and overall restaurant layout could use some work. Oh, and if you order your entree "hot", you can expect it extremely SPICY!!

I always leave full and happy.
author: Steve K.

description:
One day last week, I came for lunch on this block.  I wanted to say to So for their hot and sour noodle but there was many people already waiting and I didn't want to spend that much time there.  Therefore, I came and gave this place a chance instead.

I have been to a Henry's Hunan once, the Church Street location.  This one had a very very old feeling compared to that one.  Also, I recall the staff on the Church Street side was much more congenial.

There wasn't too much exciting on the menu (though I confess to having Cantonese or HongKong'nese bias there) so I ordered a plate with spicy smoked ham, which was okay.

Not likely to come here again unless I run into the same situation when trying to go for lunch next door and don't want to drive somewhere else.
author: H K.

description:
I went to my friend's for "take out" last night..and this time they picked up from Henry's on Bryant. 

There were three of us..but they ordered for 6--we had over 6 dishes...so we can try a variety of things family style. 

As far as greasy Chinese goes..Henry's is pretty good. The Mah Po Tofu was my favorite..tender tofu in a savory meat sauce.. 

The curry chicken was a close second..with lean white meat instead of mystery meat.  Their chow mein and fried rice were decent. The only slight disappointment was the eggplant --instead of using Asian eggplant..they used the regular eggplant which doesn't capture as much flavor. 

The only downside to Henry's is that they don't deliver. Since they are out of the way for me..I don't foresee myself taking out from this location again any time soon.
author: Mimi T.

description:
no.

so sad. I first heard of HH when a coworker said they had some of the spiciest food, but because the location he was talking about in fidi was a few blocks away from the office, I never ventured there because with only a hour lunch, I was afraid I'd have to scarf down the food and I prefer to take my time

now you know part of my rant with this location..three servers, two mainly..one of them seems to only dole out water and the free soup..and I'm assuming one or two cooks at most..this place is clearly understaffed with the traffic it gets

I snagged a table without problem or wait (others behind me, not so lucky)

I ordered the mapo tofu and request as spicy as they can make it..and licked my lips in anticipation, after all, this place was only a block away from the office I was temp. helping out..so was happy to discover this HH just around the corner.. plenty of time to eat

or so I thought, I watched as others got their food..I don't know how long they waited but I arrived at 11:15ish..order was taken ASAP mind you..at 11:45 I still haven't gotten my food and decided to flag down one of the waiters to see if it was even prepared yet, as I can just pay for my drink and be on my way,


he says its being prepared and will be out in a minute..comes out five minutes later and I have five minutes to eat before I had to pay and hurry back to the office

the biggest insult? the tofu wasn't even hot! not even mildly hot much less super spicy...

it was just average mapo tofu, waste of time and money, as I only ate a few bite full, which I dumped quite a bit of red chili pepper on..still not as hot but mildly better
author: Whitne Y.

description: I'm glad we found this place after searching a while for a good Chinese place in the area. that doesn't have breaded chicken and syrupy sauce in every dish.  The food at Henry's Hunan used high quality ingredients and everything was fresh.  My spicy Chicken and Vegetables were actually spicy and very tasty.  My wife and I also got the Eggplant salad which had a great vinaigrette.  We got takeout and I'll have to go back sometime to try some other dishes.
author: Scott L.

description: Come only if you are willing to wait for one than one hour after ordering your food. We came on a Saturday night at 7pm and ordered immediately. The store was not that busy, there were still some empty seats. But at 8:07pm, more than one hour after we ordered our food, we still didn't see a single dish on the table. I bet they must has only one cook cooking in the back.
author: Mika M.

description: Tasty, homemade Chinese food with a simple decor.  Advertised as "no MSG," yay!
author: L T.

description: Maybe I just don't pick food/restaurants  right but took 15 mins for our order to be taken,it was packed and a line at so next door so decided to come here. Place was full but most patrons seemed to have already ate. Took 20 mins to flag down waiter for a glass of water,free tea my butt! And 40 mins for our food to arrive. Sweet and sour pork and spring rolls were a whole star above Safeway. Waste of time and money.
author: Amy W.

description: Henry's food is incredible but that being said I absolutely want to scream at the staff.  They are rude and act beyond entitled.  Get a grip goddammit and respect your customers.
author: Matt F.

description:
Saw the great reviews of this place but something wasn't clicking today.

First off... the front of the house was being run REALLY poorly. Two men taking care of a whole dining room. That being said, the room had the capacity for about 60 customers (20 tables), and there were about 5 people here, at 3 tables. Shouldn't have been a big deal, but they were running around as though they were completely overwhelmed, and the service I received certainly supported this observation.

I sat down for almost ten minutes before I got up, walked to the counter, picked up a take-out menu from a plastic bin, and sat back down to read it, since I never got a menu. I then waited another five minutes until my order was taken. I ordered spring rolls and kung pao chicken. Keep it simple on my first visit, especially since it seemed like these two guys weren't really doing so well, running and yelling at each other (and into the phone when receiving phone orders).

Took ten minutes for me to get my food. In that ten minutes, I overheard two of the other three tables complaining about the service. One guy had to ask for his check and then, as he was paying for his meal, the cashier started taking a phone order and ignored him mid-transaction. I heard the customer say "It's $6.75. You owe me $5.25 back. I have to go, I'm late back to work... may I please just have my change please?". Meanwhile, another table of two was waiting for their menus after sitting for five minutes. Really bad.

My food arrived. The sweet and sour soup was mediocre. Not bad. Not good. Just there. But the kung pao was quite nice. Flavorful, fresh, and large in quantity. Too much for me for lunch, really (not that that stopped me). The spring rolls didn't show up until I was done with lunch, but to their credit, they took them off of the bill and apologized. Took another five minutes to get another soda though.

The bill came and it was still $15 with tip, even sans eggrolls, for a lunch entree and a Diet Coke. Not particularly cheap.

2.5 stars really. Horrible service though apologetic. Hole in the wall atmosphere. Lots of yelling in Mandarin between the employees. Not particularly cheap. But excellent Kung Pao. I MIGHT go back if I was in the neighborhood, in no hurry, and just craving that dish.
author: Sean B.

description: Honestly, do these jokers even run a restaurant ? My colleagues and I dropped in after the neighboring SO was closed ( and subsequently also been added to now growing list of blacklisted restaurants )  . The wait staff was completely ignorant of our arrival. It took 50 minutes for them to serve us ONE starter !! And the waitress didnt even bother getting the coke I ordered. We left without being served. I rarely get mad, but the male waiter with the bad attitude needs a lesson or two in people skills.
author: D D.

description: Excellent authentic spicy greasy yummy Chinese food. Not much of an atmosphere or service but spicy tofu is sublime and most of their chicken entrees are really good. Easy on the budget to boot. And always fast and hot and satisfying
author: Umair K.

description:
Totally affordable. That is a positive. 

The food was solid, however it was soooo salty. My friend dug the food and probably would have given this 4 stars but sadly I'm reviewing. Hence the three.

I'll be back because you are close, tasty enough and affordable.

If you read your yelp review, less salt please!!! If you do that, I'll be there frequently.
author: J. S.

description:
Gross. I got broccoli beef (amongst some other things), and you could tell that the beef was spoiled. It tasted like it was 4 days old, and left in the kitchen sink overnight before they cooked it. All the other food was oily, but not in a good way. More like in a "i'd like to make you regurgitate your dinner" kind of way. 
In addition, the place felt extremely dirty. 

I wouldn't come back.
author: Skylar W.

description:
This place has a very terrible service. 

The food was ok, but it took them a while to serve. After I was done eating, I went to the cashier to pay my bill as I was in hurry, but the waiter ignored me and didn't even say "thank you" afterwards.
author: Winny W.

description: What a Hidden Treasure!! Best Chow Mein I have had !!! The combo with steak, chicken and shrimp is huge, $10 feeds 2 people.
author: Benjamin K.

description:
Coworkers dragged me here for lunch, which is quite a walk from our office (yes, we got chewed out for a 2hr lunch).

The food is interesting and unique enough to warrant a visit, though a bit greasy at times, as mentioned in other reviews.  I also didn't think it was that spicy, though we did ask for it to be.
author: dan s.

description: Agree as to understaffing, the second round of free hot & sour soup got turned away by me nicely. I needed to go to the desk to put in my order, and I'm a pretty patient guy. The help, 2 guys and a girl were not very organized or energized, but nice enough. I saw a few smart people call ahead so their orders were ready to eat there, that's smart, the order to table time is a bit too close for comfort if you are one a 1 hour lunch. The food that went by looked good and mine was tasty when it showed, so I'll be a return TAKE OUT customer. I'm a new neighbor so I'm happy to have them to try again.
author: Neal M.

description: Came here because So next door was closed. Shittiest "Chinese" food I've had in a while. Made me crave Panda Express (yuck)
author: Rich L.

description: Pleasant surprise. Our party intended to go to SO next door which was closed.  So glad we came.  Warning: spicy IS very very spicy.
author: Chris O.

description:
This place is truly authentic.  The chefs are actually mom and pop who come from the area.  Anyways, the city is mostly filled with Guangzhou or Hong Kong style cooking.  Many of my "mid-East" (mid part of China) friends in China swear by this place.  They are just not down with Southern style food.  So, they to ask the waiter for authentic ,spicy, salty, oily entrees.  We don't even order off the menu; we just tell them what kind of dishes we want, and the chefs do the rest.

The rest of the restaurant is nothing to write home about.  The decor isn't all that great, and the layout is strange.  The service is prompt and friendly.
author: David P.

description: Best real Hunan in town. Almost pass the place since the outside looks not that good. However the food is real Hunan n the owner is amazing!!! Very spicy food n really really really good. If you are real Hunan food lover just ask Henry the real Hunan dishes not on their menu
author: Nikki Y.

description:
A fallen angel

DO NOT EAT HERE UNLESS YOU WANT TO GET SICK. NO KIDDING.

Been going to this place for the last 8 years on a fairly regular basis, obviously liked the food and the kids seemed to want to do their best.  Even drove out to that place passing another Henry's Hunan that is closer to me, trying to help the kids kind of thing.  Referred many many people to their restaurant over the years and then lately things started changing.  About 8 months ago a friend of mine who works on 10th street ate there for lunch and got violently ill.  I figured it was a one off, unfortunately turns out it was not. I did start to notice a steep decline in the quality of the food, it was no longer made with fresh vegetables, they were now often wilted and bland.  The food became much more greasy and all of it started to taste the same.  The tables were often dirty and they just swept everything off on to the floor. They had always had good rice, now I started getting a different rice, smaller and gluey and frankly just disgusting.  I brought this to their attention but they just gave me some song and dance about it being a one off, something about having run out of the "good rice" but that it was only once.  Turns out it was not, the gluey small grain garbage starting appearing more often than not.

Concurrent with this decline I witnessed a significant change of attitude as well.  The attention to the customer was gone, their standards seemed to have fallen off the face of the earth.  The restaurant became a place for the kids and their friends to hang out and they lost interest in the business, spending their time sitting at a large round table entertaining their friends even when they were not busy late in the day.  It was as if I was taking up their time and was bothering them by picking up food there and the kid running it was now seemingly above it all.  Then my family got very sick, violently sick from what was obviously food poisoning.  The hubris they exhibit is surely related to the health risk this place now poses for any one wandering in there.  I could probably overlook the lack of customer attention even the attitude but the food is now dangerous.  They have a lot to learn about dealing with the public but I intend to refer this place to the city's health inspectors as I don't think anything else will keep people from getting ill.

There are plenty of other good Chinese restaurants in the city with fresh food and no attitude; people who care about the business and not about using it as a playground for kids. Do yourself and your family a favor and avoid this place at all costs.  We will never go there again and I wish I had not referred so many people to them in the past.
author: Francis S.

description: Been here twice.  Did not care much for the food.  Everything tastes the same. Tried five different dishes.  Food doesn't seem fresh and it's all bland.  The only good item was the meat pie.  The waiter is nice though.
author: dublin a.

description:
I love coming here for lunch. It's a block from my job, and they have great noodles. Nothing amazing in that it's just simple Hunan food, but I find myself craving this place all the same. I'm going to take my brother there tomorrow :) I need to try some of the other dishes on the menu, but for now I'm sticking with the noodles and of course the MEAT PIE. Yes, I said Meat Pie and I'm not referring to English pub-grub. 

Get down, SF. Get down.
author: Peter F.

description:
I love this place since I like spicy Hunan style Chinese.  It's not high end dining, but very down to earth and homey.  Jeff's almost always there and has a big smile on and the prices are spot on.

Nice and quick service at lunch time too.  And on cold days like today the soup that comes out right away totally hits the spot - i think i'll go now!
author: Gene X.

description:
I've been coming to Henry's Hunan ever since a longtime local introduced me to the spicy rock cod dish shortly after I moved here. I like the quiet, clean and modest atmosphere at the Bryant location and the food is always good ... although my favorite (mostly vegetarian) dishes are a little heavy to eat more than once every few weeks. This is my go-to place when I need a quick escape to just relax for a moment and fuel up if we have a long day planned at work.

The Henry's staff is also very generous and lately they have been serving different kinds of flowering teas. They go above and beyond to make regular customers feel appreciated ... definitely worth checking out next time you are hungry in SoMa.
author: Lex L.

description:
I wouldn't drive clear across town for this place. Nor would I recommend it to a tourist who only has a couple of days in the city and wants a unique experience while here in San Francisco.  But I am recommending it to you, who are in the neighborhood anyway and want something different at a reasonable price.
 I really liked the sweet and sour soup which is served complimentary and was better than some I've tasted.   Sorry I can't remember the exact names of dishes, because I didn't do the ordering myself, but the "smoked meat" dishes were all excellent and the Tofu which one of the previous reviewers didn't like, I really liked. It had the soft tofu and bits of ground beef and I appreciated the abundance of sauce. So maybe it is oil, but I added some more hot oil myself from the spice rack and spread it over my rice till it soaks it. I'll upload some photos so you can see for yourself.
author: Jerome W.

description: Had to wait for 10 minutes just to sit down even though there were plenty of prepped and open tables, and another hour (not exaggerating, literally an hour) to eat. Didn't bring us a snack, didn't apologize for the wait, nothing. Food was good but nothing special, by the time it came I would have eaten an unseasoned hat.
author: Eric M.

description: Next to SO, so you might pass it up. Spicy chinese food is the name of their game. Last visit impressed me. I don't really look for service at hole in the wall places. However, my wife spilled her water, the guy working the front was like the flash. wiped it up in one second. Had napkins and a new glass of water 5 seconds later. WOW I was impressed. Food was still what it always is, cheap, fast and spicy. But that service I will never forget. Thank you flash man =)
author: Numa R.

description: I used to frequent often....Never Again  No Ice..Extremely slow service...no Dumplings.... Soy Sauce in packets....Filthy Bathroom...Employees out front smoking instead of helping...asked for hot sauce three times...Wow.... from Awesome to Never Again..... bring Jeff back to run this place correctly such a bad experience made the food a mute point....;
author: Matthew R.

description:
For office workers looking for a lunch place: if you can wait, go to SO noodles next door - it's crowded at lunch hour; if you can't, go to the McDonalds by the Hall of Justice. Just don't eat here. I tried their smoked pork and twice-cooked pork. Both were dry and hard to chew. I like their location on Natoma, but this one sucks.

I am changing my rating from 2 stars to 4 stars. My recent experience has been good.
author: YM L.

description:
Your orange chicken tastes like fruit loops.

Eek! Methinks not.
author: Lisa W.

description:
The old Henry was such a liar and a cheater because 2 reasons.

1. He said that the best chow-mein in the city In the old menu.
    
How could you said that?
How can you measure in what degree and said, "Umm, this is the best      
chow mein ever!"
I love chow-mein so bad, I can eat any time in any day but ...The best chow-mein?
Chow-mein is the most mediocre food that even I can make my own and that'll be the best in the city.

2. Old Henry has a dumbA'ss 1st great-grand son who plucked his senior year of Sacred Heart high school but the old Henry donated huge amount of money to save his dumbAss 1st great-grand son to graduate.
So, he did, graduated by money.
What the Fxxx?
If you are a rich MozaFxxxer like the old Henry, you can graduate the high school with no grade.

What a screwed up!

But, It's a new owner, but of course it's related. 
The waitress is the old Henry's Great-Great Grand daughter.
And her father ISN'T the dumbAss 1st grand son, but he is the new owner and cook.
They are hard working people.
Food is pretty good.
The bathrooms are very clean for Chinese restaurant.
And the new menu doesn't say "the best chow mein" at all.

I'll come back.

Jeff- the old owner who told me the all story of the old Henry, opened a new Henry's on Church and 24th Street. Haven't been there yet.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Do you want to know what happens when you ask a Chinese girl to order food for her white friends?  A world of pain happens.  And MSG.  

I'm not sure how I manage to make such a mess of it all.  But I blame SO.  It was closed.  On a Monday, NOT Memorial day.  I should have known when I tried to call and place an order for pickup, when they didn't answer.  I should have given up.  But no.  

The lunch was certainly cheap.  And the portions huge.  But just don't try to be an Asian girl ordering for white friends who can't handle spice.  Seriously.  It felt so wrong.  

I'm giving up Chinese food for Lent.  And Summer.  And the rest of my life.  Don't ever let me into a Chinese restaurant.  Don't ever let me order Chinese food.  Because I will eff it up.  Badly.
author: Christina C.

description: I love Henry's! Great Kung Pao Beef and Chicken. All of the hot and sour dishes are delicious. The lunch rush is a nightmare, but if you can get in there after that, it's a quiet, enjoyable dining experience. I like the decor and the staff is frendly, too.
author: Jamie A.

description: This restaurant is under new management  after June of 2010. The food over there is really traditional and delicious. Like henry's special, Kung pao chicken, harvest pork. Also Diana's meat pie and Chinese dumplings are the best appetizers I ever had. I hope everyone can try these dishes.
author: Hao Z.

description: Really good affordable Chinese food that is both authentic yet American friendly. The menu has a great selection of traditional dishes that is both delicious and well-priced. The meat pie is an awesome, unique dish; it is a Chinese Chalupa that was probably conceived by a drunkard with muchies. I love the flavors and spiciness of the dishes. Service is fast and restaurant is clean. Although, I am a little insulted they gave me a fork and an all English menu even though I am Chinese.
author: Ed L.

description:
*Drool*

Lipsmacking greasy food. Its really tasty but dont try shying away from calories when you dine here. Its very damaging for the waistline but your taste buds will love you. Its quite economical too. Losing those pounds- ahem ahem not so economical. 

Tried their Fried rice,Veggie chowmein and Five bean curd curry. All were par excellence. I feel the urge to eat here every week and of course I show up,and my burgeoning ass only gets bigger.

 *Sigh*
author: Natasha I.

description: It's under new management now and it's much better than the previous one. And I love the new paint here! The food is way better too! Plus, it's cheaper to get the same food than other Henry's Hunan locations! I love this place.
author: Grace J.

description: Decent surprise!  We went into the restaurant with very low expectations thinking its another Americanized Chinese food place..  Until we started chatting with the server and gently probed if they have a Chineses menu.  The server patiently and kindly explained that they didn't have one, but they can make certain dishes that're off the menu.  There were only a few items on this "special menu" and we ordered everything from it: stir-fried ferns, Chinese bacons, stir-friend tofu and meat.  We also got a hot sour soup.  Every dish is delicious reminds me of food I get at home.  There're also items you can call and reserve ahead of time like Pickled chili chicken/fish.  I'm definitely going back to try those special dishes :)
author: Michelle W.

description:
I couldn't bear people coming here hoping for some nice Chinese flavors because it has 3.5 stars on yelp. If you're looking for good flavor, this really is not the place. This is not about unauthentic, it's not about Americanized Chinese food: it just tastes bad. The hot and sour soup is so salty. I felt like the ingredients had their original flavors ripped off and replaced with salt and sauce. So sad. 

The portions were huge. I asked to have half dine-in and half to go -- and I couldn't finish either portion. Partly because it's more comforting to stay hungry than to finish it. 

Yes don't come here next time SO's closed. Walk another block to Sunrise Cafe.
author: Liz H.

description: One of my favorite Chinese restaurants.  Decent prices.  I love the meat pie and noodles with pork meat and Hunan special sauce.
author: Brian C.

description: Foods above average, been coming here for 3yrs and it could use a remodeling or just new paint but other than that, I would recommend for lunch.
author: Johnny H.

description: Not a bad chinese place, but there are certainly many options in San Francisco.  It's proximity to where I was working at though made it completely convenient for me to go there to grab a quick meal.  The flavors to me tasted good, and the service is quick and simple.  Not much of an experience at this place, but great if you want good food real fast.
author: Lawrence C.

description: The few times that i've gone here, there was plenty of seating. I always get the spicy rock cod fillet. it's sooo damn good i sometimes have dreams about it. The people that work there are nice, venue is interesting...due to the paint colors, but the food is what i come here for, so i dont care about the ambience.
author: Darnell L.

description:
I like Americanized Chinese food.  I suspect this might have something to do with the fact that I'm an American who was born and raised in the Midwest.

Actually, I have a pretty sophisticated palate and a wide range of cuisine I enjoy.  Authentic Chinese food didn't make the cut.  I'm just not down with noshing on duck tongues and chicken feet.

So, there are my biases.  Now on to the rest of the review.

Quality of Food: Better than your average take out.  The very high levels of salt and oils make things tasty.  As with most tasty things, this isn't very healthy.

Variety: They have a solid variety of dish names.  Like most Americanized chinese or mexican restaurants, it's a different combination of the same six ingredients.

Service: The table service is pretty good for a busy lunch rush.  Solid.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I went here because a friend said it was the best chinese food in the world. Really? Better than in China? I bet there are like a 100 million chinese joints out there.

It was really good quality food, and really spicy.  But I will wait till I make it to China proper before I give it the best in the world title. 
Service was good also. Friendly.
author: Brendan R.

description:
I know two people that claim this is their favorite Chinese in the City and would give it five stars, but it's my review so it gets four.

Pros: 
Jeff - the waiter who is nice, not in a "I want a big tip" kind of way, but in a "I was born with a smile on my face and always remember your name and what you like to eat" kind of way.  He's on top of the whole dining room whether there's one table or it's full.

Healthy? - Well, they certainly claim to be on the healthier side of the Chinese food scale, which is similar to saying healthier side of the Soul Food scale, but whatever, it makes you feel just a little bit less guilty about eating Chinese.  No MSG, fresh ingredients, and plenty of vegetarian choices, although the meat dishes are too good not to order.

Tasty - The food is really good.  You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  Adjust the spice to your taste.

Cons: 
Zero ambiance.  My school cafeteria had more charm.

http://www.cleanscores.com/2715/Henry%27s+Hunan+Restaurant
author: Ann W.

description:
Decent, flavorful Chinese food in outer SoMa
Got the shredded pork Chow Mein, appropriate spice levels, tasty and needed nothing
Personally prefer Chow Fun (wide) style rice noodles, but unless they are fresh and cooked properly (not an easy thing to find) they can be yucky

Decent size seating area
Very hole-in-the-wall-esque, nothing fancy
Not the type of place you'd want to bring a date to impress, unless you're a take out and movie at home type of gal, in that case, u need to contact me immediately :)

Will go back for lunch sometime, when the mood strikes

TIP: no w i f i there (yes put the spaces so non searchable)
author: G K.

description:
*sigh*.  

if you're goign to make bad chinese food, the least you can do is throw some MSG on there. Seriously, when the quality of ingredients is crappy, you have no choice but to mask it, either with Spice or with MSG!

I only came because the line at SO was too long (I suspect its' where they get most of their business).  

I'll try not to come back... I'm sure there's a place down the street with some MSG on top!
author: Joseph F.

description:
I've been eating here for a good year now and I would have to say that it's consistently good - I usually go with my co-workers for lunch and order close to the same thing - 

string beans with shrimp - 
napa cabbage - 
chicken chow mien - 

the lunch comes with hot and sour soup which pretty good on a cold day - It's very salty and the spice varies but for the most part they make it hot -
author: Tony G.

description:
They smoke the meat themselves, staff make Pork Buns in their slack time. Friendly and good size portions. Mu Shu soup and the smoked meat special (chicken and pork) with rice is a satisfying meal for two. 

Not to sure about Dianna's meat pie - something like a Chinese Tostada but try once and you decide. 

Recommended.
author: Niall M.

description:
Talk about GREASY! Everything tastes the same whether it's chicken or shrimp, green beans or broccoli. It's all got the same sick sauce on it.
Put it this way, last time our office ordered take out from this place I found a giant BOLT in my kung pao chicken. 
No joke. Keep an eye out when you eat this stuff!!!
author: Melissa W.

description:
Every office worker needs a cheap chinese place nearby to drown their sorrows in tea and spicy sauce.  Sort of the lunch equivalent of a dive bar.  For me, that place is Henry's Hunan.  It's divey, atmosphere-wise, but this isn't the Sunset, so the menu caters to westerners both in selection and, well, language.  They make a big deal about their no MSG, no extra sugar policy, so I was curious to see how the orange chicken would fare under such rules.  Sure enough, it wasn't drowning in syrup, and the flavor that was there tasted unusually fresh.  And it was even spicy!  Dunno if I'd call it "healthy", though; the breading still seemed pretty bad for you.  

Friendly service and some extremely cheap lunch specials too.  Not a lot of choices for Chinese around here but you could do a lot worse.
author: Wes M.

description:
When I was at the nearby courthouse for jury duty I asked the employees in the building where they go for lunch. They mentioned this place.

Very solid hole-in-the wall Chinese food. The food here comes piping hot right off the Wok. I love the Hunan smoked ham with vegetables over rice. They don't skimp on the spice. It makes me happy that I can get a great big spicy lunch for 5 dollars. The chopsticks of the Hunan region are longer than others too- lands more comfortably in my hands. 

Go here before you go across the street to Trader Joe's because its a disaster going to the grocery store while hungry. Also, when you do your jury duty go here.
author: David S.

description:
It was meh. I have been traveling around the Bay looking for GOOD mapo tofu, and i have NOT found it at Henry's Hunan. The beef bits with bean curd (i think thats a direct quote from the menu) was hardly flavorful and just mreh. and yes, I asked the waiter if that equated mapo tofu and he said yes. 

On the other hand, I enjoyed the little complimentary bowls of soup, and the dumplings were pretty tasty. i think they're handmade somewhere or another, but it was pretty good.

The other food my colleagues got was pretty meh too. Its nice to switch it up and get away from the office, but I just meh.
author: Jade L.

description:
Fresh and hot chicken -- like my love life (I have NO idea what that means)! Every time I've been here, I've been in the middle of six hundred errands to be done in the immediate area (Trader Joe's, mailing Netflix, being "foine," etc.) so I always run in out of breath and hurried, sputtering something like, 
"thekungpaospicyyeahoki'mgonnaberightbackok?" - very similar to the part in Goodfellas (ey, fuggit about it!) where Henry's doing his errands in a coke frenzy.   Seriously the freshest chicken I've had at a cheapo Chinese food place in ages.  Free Tibet!
author: J P.

description:
By far the best of the Henry's Hunan family of restaurants that I've been to. Love the greasily delicious chicken chow mein and the free hot & sour at lunch.

Michael is super swell, especially if you become a regular, although I get the sneaking suspicion that he runs the place with a Mao-like fist once the kitchen doors shut.

This place is the only thing I truly miss about working in that area.
author: RT G.

description:
OK, so I feel bad writing a negative review of this place, but it'll balance out all the overly positive reviews. It did have AMAZING hot and sour soup-- so if you're a fan of that dish, you should come here for that alone. The green bean dish and stir-fried beef with green onions were decent. Also, the service is friendly and it's one of the few restaurants near the Concourse if you're heading there for a concert, show etc.

But, out of the other 4 or 5 dishes we ordered, the rest of them were just bad. Diana's special or the onion cake with ground meat reminded everyone of dog food. Even the rice was hard and tasted old-- they screwed up white rice at a Chinese restaurant!!! other dishes tasted overly salty, had way too much stir-fried onion (cheaper than meat or veggies I presume), or were just mleh... now you know, you've been warned
author: Amy D.

description:
Another lunch staple of my SOMA working days. Never could understand why we came here so much cuz there's nothing special about this place -- probably cuz I worked with a bunch of Bok-gwai (white people). However, they did have this meat pie thingy -- 2 deep fried onion pancakes filled with meat. Damn greasy but damn good. 

To balance out the greasy meat oreo (or so the logic works in my head), I always ordered the cold chicken noodles -- chicken, noodles, julienned cucumbers and peanut sauce. Good stuff.
author: Law W.

description:
Henry's Hunan reminds me of the chinese restaurant at the end of A Christmas Story.

Although the restaurant is located next to the freeway, it has that hole in the wall feel. And the staff might sing you Deck the Halls, while decapitating a roast duck right in front of you.

The food is hit or miss on a lot of occasions.  The Hunan Smoked Ham with Vegetables was insanely salty; compounded with the heat that the dish was packing, I was ready to dunk my head into a trough of water. Thankfully, the Dry-Sauteed String Beans and Tofu with rice noodles and vegetables brought relief.

Although the scallop and shrimp dishes were nothing special, the Orange Chicken and the Beef with Vegetables were two of the better ones on the menu.
author: Sam T.

description:
I love this spot Jeff is the best he always knows exactly what  
 we want(because we always get the same thing)..If you like  spicy then you need to check this place out...Family Owned ( Jeff's   uncle)n the food is always consistent try one of these  dishes if you go

  Tofu with the clear noodles(not the name but ask for it)
  Hunan Special Orange Sauce Chicken 
  Spicy and Hot Rock Fillets 

 There is always parking
author: Kim R.

description:
Why should you eat at this Henry's?  Let me give you some reasons:

1. Orange chicken
2. Kung Pao anything
3. Chow Mein (best in town, the menu says - and it ain't lying!)
4. Becuase this guy when to the trouble of trying EVERY SINGLE DISH on the menu so you don't have to: http://greasepig.com/henrys/
5. Becuase Jeff is the only server I've ever seen keep a very large dining room full of customers completely happy all by himself.

Bottom line: if you like spicy, greasyspoon, chinese food then look no further.  This is the THE place.
author: Josh L.

description:
So I went once and I'm probably not going again. The chicken chow mein did not work for me, even though I hadn't eaten in 8 hours it didn't taste good. It had a good toasty flavor, but it didn't have that yumminess. 

The lady working in the front was really nice tho. I really wish this place was amazing so I could come by very often.
author: Mary H.

description:
A friend in concord mentioned that all the locals know that Henry's is the best. Another local confirmed it and I went off to try it out.

They have the best hot n sour soup i've tasted anywhere. I've yet to make it past dishes with hot bean curd sauce. amazing. I've also had fantastic service the times I've went as well.
author: Karsten M.

description:
Dear Henry, 
Please marry me and come live at my house. Your orange chicken always makes me feel better about myself, and plus, you're really super nice. I only ever see you by yourself in the restaurant, during the evening hours during which I come, and you serve the whole house with a big smile. I have never seen a chef. I think perhaps your food is made by magic, which is why it is so yummy.
author: Carleigh K.

description: Slowest Chinese restaurant ever.   We never even ended up getting our food.  After being seated, it was about 5 minutes before we were offered menus and 10 minutes later before were finally able to flag down the waitress to order.  Ok, no big deal.  We ordered a few dishes, including hot and sour soup.  Meanwhile, the waitress kept shuffling back and forth, avoiding eye contact.  About 35 minutes later we flagged her down again and asked how much longer it would be.  She said there were still 4 or so tables in front of us.  Having observed that food had been coming out at a rate of one table every 5 minutes (apparently they only cook for one table at a time), we decided we weren't willing to wait ANOTHER 20 minutes for crappy Chinese food, and told the waitress we were leaving.  Instead of apologizing, she seemed relieved.  Come on, they've got to at least have a vat of hot and sour soup back in the kitchen. It shouldn't take an hour to bring out something as simple as that.
author: natilee r.

description:
A Chinese woman friend once told me that the only good Chinese Restaurants are the ones that have formica tables and flouresent lights.  Well, this fits that description.  Infact, they actually didn't completely take out the old kitchen when they "remodeled" and you can see the enormous satinless steel wall and hood of the old stove right in the dining room.  Gots to love tat.  

Anyways, Jeffery (or Jeff) is a wonderful Chinese young man who works there constantly.  Seriously he's ALWAYS there.  I asked him about it and he says he NEVER gets a day off, holidays included as long as it's during the week.  He feels blessed that he doesn't have to work weekends because the place is closed, so he doesn't complain.  
I look forward to discussing the Giants and A's with him.  He gets so excited by the prospect of baseball season and perhaps the Giants going all the way.  Unfortunately, the more excited he gets the less I understand, me being a white boy from CT.      ...and now that they've got Zito (yeah, I'm an A's freak) I can start rooting for the Gi's! 

So say Hi to Jeffery and then go straignt on to order the Harvest Pork.  I freakin' LOVE that stuff. I seriously cannot order anything else. A am addicted and, NO, I won't go to counseling.
author: doug b.

description: got there early and food still took over an hour for first dishes to arrive. wait wasn't worth it as food was not anything to make the wait worthwhile. only saving grace was it was cheap, but you pay for what you get.
author: Ian V.

description:
The place is very close to my work. Im only alloted 30 minutes for most lunches, so I love to go here. 
The food is prepared very quickly. The cooks can bust out 3 orders in about 7 minutes. 

The guy behind the counter, didnt catch his name, is ALWAYS up for a chat and is very friendly and personable. 

The food is SPICY!!! Do not pass up the opportunity to order something spicy off the menu. 
Once I ordered veggies and tofu without the spice and it was too bland. lol

Good choice for vegetarians and people who want to eat less meat in their diet. Plenty to choose from.
author: joanna r.

description: HOT & SOUR SOUP (MY FAVE) is a MUST HAVE, especially in our SF FOG WEATHER! Their braised cod fillets, smoked ham & string beans, and noodles and pork sauce are to die for! i can't say enough about this place.. we get take-out at the office and they are always friendly with us since we're regulars. they even offer us discount coupons here and there!!!!!! talk about customer service and keeping their customers happy! their dishes are delicious, plentiful, and a lot of bang for your buck! :) you won't be disappointed!
author: Danielle C.

description: Dumplings and Green Bean Chicken are a must have. If you like hot that can make you sweat ask for it spicy. They don't mind making it mild for those faint of heart. This place is great for family style meals and groups. So come hungry and leave happy.
author: Charlene K.

description:
I gave this place 3 chances and I felt like an idiot the third time. Food is bland, greasy, and BIG portions. I was never even able to eat half my plate, gave it to a bum right outside the place  when I was being polite and asked for a doggy bag. I wonder what he would rate it? 

You want good chinese food in the area go to eliza's.
author: T S.

description:
Henry, when I tasted your meat pie, I heard angel's trumpets and devil's trombones. It was gorgeousness and gorgeousity made into an appetizer. Thank you.

Oh, I should mention also that apparently Henry is dead. Is it weird to write a paean in such a way to a dead man? I hope not, because I could write more florid, flowing prose about his namesake restaurant's dishes (try the Hot and Sour Beef), hilariously outdated signage (described justly as "bowling alley"-esque), and ample water (stretching here, but it was at optimal drinking temperature).
